19.heading: Romance Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Articles About.
19.title: "Le Roman DessinÃ© : un 'Film en Planches DessinÃ©es'"
19.author: Sylviette Giet
19.appears_in: p. 44-51 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du MusÃ©e de la Bande DessinÃ©e, no. 6 (Jan. 2001).
notes: Begins: "Parmi les multiples bandes dessinÃ©es proposÃ©es au lectorat fÃ©minin, un partie d'entre elles relÃ¨vent d'un sous-genre spÃ©cifique, dÃ©signÃ© par ses Ã©diteurs comme 'roman dessinÃ©'. Un sous-genre qui sera un des grands succÃ¨s de la presse d'aprÃ¨s-guerre, et fondera celui de la 'presse du cÅur'. Mais ce roman sentimental en images tend Ã  se prÃ©senter come substitut de film plus que comme bande dessinÃ©e."

English summary (from page 150): "A Film in Comic Strip Form. Before being replaced by the fumetti, the 'graphic novel' which presented itself as a substitute for a film, constituted an important part of romance publications in post war years. Sylvette Giet recounts the brief acme of this genre that originated in Italy and in which some great artists such as Walter Molino distinguished themselves."

77.heading: Romance Fiction.
77.title: Flight of Magic
77.author: Jacqueline Diamond.
notes: "What was the quintessential high-powered businesswoman doing with a laid-back cartoonist who'd lampooned her in a nationally syndicated comic strip? Eating Larry Toland's gooey desserts. Enjoying him in his role as the neighborhood Pied Piper. And wondering what it would be like to fall in love. Beth Macon was at home in a business suit. At her best when closing a deal. And at a total loss when it came to romance. Even if Beth found the time, could she learn to let go and surrender to the passion she saw in Larry's eyes?"
